{{new page}} [[File:Chetniks in Belgrade, 1920.jpg|thumb|right|Chetniks on parade in Belgrade, {{circa|1920}}.]] [[File:Association against Bulgarian Bandits.jpg|thumb|right|Association against Bulgarian Bandits, between 1922 and 1925.]] [[File:Chetnik Association, 1920s.jpg|thumb|right|Chetnik Association, between 1921 and 1926.]] In the '''Interwar period''' in [[Yugoslavia]] (1918–41), there were several veteran associations of Serbian guerrillas (known as "Chetniks") that had fought in Ottoman Macedonia (1903–12), Balkan Wars (1912–13) and World War I (1914–18). Leading Chetniks were split between the [[Democratic Party (Yugoslavia)|Democratic Party]] (DS) and [[People's Radical Party|Radical Party]] (RS), and also between ties to the secret societies of the [[Black Hand (Serbia)|Black Hand]] and [[White Hand (Serbia)|White Hand]].{{sfn|Tomasevich|1975}} These ideological differences led to the formation of several '''Chetnik associations'''. The first assocation, established in 1921, was split corresponding to the [[Yugoslavist]] DS and [[Serbian nationalist]] RS in 1924.{{sfn|Newman|2015|pp=104–106}} The most important figures in the Chetnik movement in this period were [[Puniša Račić]], [[Ilija Trifunović-Birčanin]] and [[Kosta Milovanović-Pećanac]].{{sfn|Newman|2015|p=104}} ==Background== {{see also|Serbian Chetnik Organization|Chetniks in the Balkan Wars|Chetniks in occupied Serbia (1916–18)}} The [[Serbian Chetnik Organization]], founded by Serbian activists, organized guerrilla units dispatched into Ottoman territories to the south of the [[Kingdom of Serbia]].{{sfn|Newman|2015|p=30}} In the 1904–12 period these guerrilla units conducted warfare in Macedonia, seeking to liberate the region and join it with Serbia.{{sfn|Tomasevich|1975|p=116}} At first privately organized, it's directions were soon taken over by the Serbian government.{{sfn|Tomasevich|1975|p=116}} The guerrilla action accompanied the dissemination of nationalist propaganda (nationalization).{{sfn|Newman|2015|p=31}} The Chetniks, as an [[auxiliaries|auxiliary]] force, played an active role in the [[Balkan Wars]] and [[World War I]].{{harvnb|Newman|2015|p=32}}, {{harvnb|Tomasevich|1975|pp=117–118}} ==History== {{empty section|date=November 2016}} ==Associations== {| class="wikitable" |- !
